titleStmt.author: Mrs. A. R. Barnes

sourceDesc.p: A cookbook and household guide made for British settlers in Africa.

div.head: Plum Pudding, No. 3
div.p: The grated crumbs of 6 small breakfast rolls, 3 cups flour, 1 lb. stoned raisins, 1 lb. currants, 1 lb. fine beef suet, 1/2 grated nutmeg, 1 cup of milk, a little ground cinnamon, 1 teacupful sugar, some pounded 23 Naartje: clementine or.... naartje peel, 1 saltspoonful salt, 1 wineglass French brandy, some mixed candied peel, the juice of 2 or 3 lemons, 6, 8, or 10 eggs, or an ostrich egg. Boil six hours in a mould.

div.head: Curry and Rice.
div.p: Cut the meat up very small. Fresh uncooked meat is necessarily the best. Fredge it with flour, and place the meat at the bottom of a saucepan with has some melted fat in it, add some sliced onions pepper,and salt, and as much dry curry powderdry curry powder as is liked. Some people and children care for only sufffiecient to flavour it, whilist others like it very strong and hot. Cartwright's curry powder (Cape Town) is the best to be obtained in the colony. It is prepared from an old and valuable recipe.

Dissolve some tamarind in hot water, add its liquor, of if no tamarind is at hand a very small pinch of tartaric acid gives the same flavour. Stir all well together until the meat browns nicely, then add as much hot water as will cover the whole, put in the potatoes soon after if they are to be cooked with it, skim off all the fat, and prcoeed to boil until the meat is tender. If, when ready, the curry needs thickening, mix into a smooth paste a little maizenaCorn starch, cornstarch, cornflour

Mix 1 cup of arrowroot with 1 cup of butter well, then add 1 cup of sugar, pinch of salt, and 1 teaspoonful of carbonate of soda. Beat 3 eggswell, and add them to it. Mix well together and bake in patty pans.
